title: How to Create a Neopoprealist Art Work

steps.headline: Research the basic concepts of NeoPoprealism.
steps.description: Started by Nadia Russ in 1989, this art style is not interested in copying real-life objects, the human body, or the ideas of others. It focuses on breaking through limitations and opening your mind in order to create artworks that are unique. You can do extensive research on this art form by looking for books on NeoPopRealism and taking classes that involve it in the curriculum. Along with being an art style, it can be meditative and a great way to relieve aggression due to its repetitive patterns.

steps.headline: Learn the 10 canons of NeoPopRealism.
steps.description: NeoPopRealism is a style of art, but it is also a philosophy. The philosophy of this form is important because it influences how the art is created and what it looks like. Created by Russ, the 10 canons are:Be beautiful. Be creative and productive. Never stop studying and learning. Be peace-loving and positive-minded. Do not accept communistic philosophy. Be free-minded. Do the best you can to move the world towards peace and harmony. Be family oriented and self-disciplined. Believe in God. God is one. Be supportive to those who need you. Be generous. Create your life as a great adventure story.

steps.headline: Look up NeoPopRealism works by artists.
steps.description: It’s important to learn about the style, but it’s also important to see what the style looks like. You can do an online search for NeoPopRealism. You can also look directly on Nadia Russ’s website for examples. Nadia Russ also has a YouTube channel where she draws an example of her style.

steps.headline: Familiarize yourself with the basic techniques.
steps.description: Because NeoPopRealism is supposed to stem from a deep place within your imagination, you are not supposed to think about what you’re drawing. There aren’t many solid techniques like there are in other styles of art. There are, however, a few basic techniques. First, you would typically start with a solid outline. This outline can be anything—like a face or a car. Then, divide the object into sections and fill in these sections with repetitive patterns.For example, you could fill in the sections with repeated circles, dots and swirls. Essentially, take an ink pen and begin to create the repetitive patterns.

steps.headline: Create repetitive patterns on a piece of paper without focusing on the results.
steps.description: You have to be familiar with the style to begin practicing. Take out a blank piece of paper and a pencil. Begin to create. Right now, the goal is to open up your mind and forget restrictions. Be unique. Never copy.

steps.headline: Try a basic pattern.
steps.description: If you do want some guidelines, try to draw basic patterns. For example, start with a square. Then, fill the square with patterns. For example, you could fill it with a lot of small circles, triangles and wavy lines.

steps.headline: Turn your practice drawing the repetitive patterns into a sketch.
steps.description: Basically, you should use the lines to create the shape and sections. Then, fill the sections with different patterns and ornaments. If you can’t think of what to draw, draw a line that resembles the profile of a face. It is actually the most interesting and sophisticated thing to draw. Then, draw the basic features of that face with loose lines and shapes.

steps.headline: Draw the profile of a face.
steps.description: Simple draw the outline of a forehead, eye, nice, mouth, and chin. Fill in the face with basic features if you desire, or use patterns to draw an abstract version of a face. A face is an example, but you can draw whatever you want.

steps.headline: Use a pen to draw your sketch.
steps.description: You need a sketch only if you prepare for a large, the wall-size artwork like a mirror. You need no preparation or sketches if you draw the small or medium size artwork. Nadia Russ recommends using always a pen to draw in this style so that you can’t erase what you’ve created. It’s okay if the drawing looks different from what you’ve expected it would be or if you make mistakes. Use your sense of harmony to fix the composition without eraser. Do not give up until you feel the drawing is complete.Deciding when the drawing is complete is entirely up to you. You can stop whenever you can’t think of anything else to add to the drawing. The best judge here is your sense of harmony.

steps.headline: Draw several patterns.
steps.description: You can dive into creating the egg if you’d like, but if you are a beginner, it’s okay to start by generating ideas by drawing patterns. Take out a piece of paper and a pen. Never use a pencil. Fill the paper with several separate and unique patterns. You can use those patterns to fill in your egg when you’re ready.For example, you can draw repeated diamonds, circles, swirls, curvy lines and triangles.

steps.headline: Draw an egg shape on paper.
steps.description: Once you’ve come up with some patterns, draw the shape of an egg on a piece of paper. You should only draw the basic outline, and the inside of the “egg” should be empty. It’s okay if the shape isn’t perfect, but you can redraw it if you aren’t happy with the first shape.

steps.headline: Fill the egg with lines and patterns.
steps.description: You can put some thought into this if you are a beginner or do it entirely without putting conscious effort into what you’re drawing. Section your egg off by drawing several lines so that you create “spaces” for your patterns. Then, fill those spaces with patterns like the ones you practiced. Don’t stop until the entire egg has been filled—unless you want to leave white space.

steps.headline: Paint your pattern onto a wooden egg.
steps.description: Your artwork can be finished when you complete the egg on paper, or you can use that egg as a base for a wooden egg. This isn’t necessary, but it is a way to show off and display what you’ve created. Take a wooden egg and acrylic paint in the colors of your choice. Use a thin paintbrush to paint patterns all over the wooden egg. Wait a few minutes for the paint to dry and then finish by spraying it with a clear varnish.It’s also an option to use transfer paper if you don’t want to start the sketch over completely. You can also use a marker or pen to draw on the egg if you don’t want to use paint.

text: Learning about NeoPopRealism Research the basic concepts of NeoPoprealism. Started by Nadia Russ in 1989, this art style is not interested in copying real-life objects, the human body, or the ideas of others. It focuses on breaking through limitations and opening your mind in order to create artworks that are unique. You can do extensive research on this art form by looking for books on NeoPopRealism and taking classes that involve it in the curriculum. Along with being an art style, it can be meditative and a great way to relieve aggression due to its repetitive patterns. Learn the 10 canons of NeoPopRealism. NeoPopRealism is a style of art, but it is also a philosophy. The philosophy of this form is important because it influences how the art is created and what it looks like. Created by Russ, the 10 canons are:Be beautiful. Be creative and productive. Never stop studying and learning. Be peace-loving and positive-minded. Do not accept communistic philosophy. Be free-minded. Do the best you can to move the world towards peace and harmony. Be family oriented and self-disciplined. Believe in God. God is one. Be supportive to those who need you. Be generous. Create your life as a great adventure story. Look up NeoPopRealism works by artists. It’s important to learn about the style, but it’s also important to see what the style looks like. You can do an online search for NeoPopRealism. You can also look directly on Nadia Russ’s website for examples. Nadia Russ also has a YouTube channel where she draws an example of her style. Familiarize yourself with the basic techniques. Because NeoPopRealism is supposed to stem from a deep place within your imagination, you are not supposed to think about what you’re drawing. There aren’t many solid techniques like there are in other styles of art. There are, however, a few basic techniques. First, you would typically start with a solid outline. This outline can be anything—like a face or a car. Then, divide the object into sections and fill in these sections with repetitive patterns.For example, you could fill in the sections with repeated circles, dots and swirls. Essentially, take an ink pen and begin to create the repetitive patterns. Practicing NeoPopRealism Create repetitive patterns on a piece of paper without focusing on the results. You have to be familiar with the style to begin practicing. Take out a blank piece of paper and a pencil. Begin to create. Right now, the goal is to open up your mind and forget restrictions. Be unique. Never copy. Try a basic pattern. If you do want some guidelines, try to draw basic patterns. For example, start with a square. Then, fill the square with patterns. For example, you could fill it with a lot of small circles, triangles and wavy lines. Turn your practice drawing the repetitive patterns into a sketch. Basically, you should use the lines to create the shape and sections. Then, fill the sections with different patterns and ornaments. If you can’t think of what to draw, draw a line that resembles the profile of a face. It is actually the most interesting and sophisticated thing to draw. Then, draw the basic features of that face with loose lines and shapes. Draw the profile of a face. Simple draw the outline of a forehead, eye, nice, mouth, and chin. Fill in the face with basic features if you desire, or use patterns to draw an abstract version of a face. A face is an example, but you can draw whatever you want. Use a pen to draw your sketch. You need a sketch only if you prepare for a large, the wall-size artwork like a mirror. You need no preparation or sketches if you draw the small or medium size artwork. Nadia Russ recommends using always a pen to draw in this style so that you can’t erase what you’ve created. It’s okay if the drawing looks different from what you’ve expected it would be or if you make mistakes. Use your sense of harmony to fix the composition without eraser. Do not give up until you feel the drawing is complete.Deciding when the drawing is complete is entirely up to you. You can stop whenever you can’t think of anything else to add to the drawing. The best judge here is your sense of harmony. Creating a NeoPopRealism Egg Draw several patterns. You can dive into creating the egg if you’d like, but if you are a beginner, it’s okay to start by generating ideas by drawing patterns. Take out a piece of paper and a pen. Never use a pencil. Fill the paper with several separate and unique patterns. You can use those patterns to fill in your egg when you’re ready.For example, you can draw repeated diamonds, circles, swirls, curvy lines and triangles. Draw an egg shape on paper. Once you’ve come up with some patterns, draw the shape of an egg on a piece of paper. You should only draw the basic outline, and the inside of the “egg” should be empty. It’s okay if the shape isn’t perfect, but you can redraw it if you aren’t happy with the first shape. Fill the egg with lines and patterns. You can put some thought into this if you are a beginner or do it entirely without putting conscious effort into what you’re drawing. Section your egg off by drawing several lines so that you create “spaces” for your patterns. Then, fill those spaces with patterns like the ones you practiced. Don’t stop until the entire egg has been filled—unless you want to leave white space. Paint your pattern onto a wooden egg. Your artwork can be finished when you complete the egg on paper, or you can use that egg as a base for a wooden egg. This isn’t necessary, but it is a way to show off and display what you’ve created. Take a wooden egg and acrylic paint in the colors of your choice. Use a thin paintbrush to paint patterns all over the wooden egg. Wait a few minutes for the paint to dry and then finish by spraying it with a clear varnish.It’s also an option to use transfer paper if you don’t want to start the sketch over completely. You can also use a marker or pen to draw on the egg if you don’t want to use paint.

Started by Nadia Russ in 1989, this art style is not interested in copying real-life objects, the human body, or the ideas of others.
It focuses on breaking through limitations and opening your mind in order to create artworks that are unique.
You can do extensive research on this art form by looking for books on NeoPopRealism and taking classes that involve it in the curriculum.
Along with being an art style, it can be meditative and a great way to relieve aggression due to its repetitive patterns.
Learn the 10 canons of NeoPopRealism.
NeoPopRealism is a style of art, but it is also a philosophy.
The philosophy of this form is important because it influences how the art is created and what it looks like.
Created by Russ, the 10 canons are:Be beautiful.
Be creative and productive.
Never stop studying and learning.
Be peace-loving and positive-minded.
Do not accept communistic philosophy.
Be free-minded.
Do the best you can to move the world towards peace and harmony.
Be family oriented and self-disciplined.
Believe in God.
God is one.

Be generous.
Create your life as a great adventure story.

You can also look directly on Nadia Russ’s website for examples.
Nadia Russ also has a YouTube channel where she draws an example of her style.
Familiarize yourself with the basic techniques.
Because NeoPopRealism is supposed to stem from a deep place within your imagination, you are not supposed to think about what you’re drawing.
There aren’t many solid techniques like there are in other styles of art.
There are, however, a few basic techniques.
First, you would typically start with a solid outline.
This outline can be anything—like a face or a car.
Then, divide the object into sections and fill in these sections with repetitive patterns.For example, you could fill in the sections with repeated circles, dots and swirls.
Essentially, take an ink pen and begin to create the repetitive patterns.
Practicing NeoPopRealism Create repetitive patterns on a piece of paper without focusing on the results.
You have to be familiar with the style to begin practicing.
Take out a blank piece of paper and a pencil.
Begin to create.
Right now, the goal is to open up your mind and forget restrictions.
Be unique.

Try a basic pattern.
If you do want some guidelines, try to draw basic patterns.
For example, start with a square.
Then, fill the square with patterns.
For example, you could fill it with a lot of small circles, triangles and wavy lines.
Turn your practice drawing the repetitive patterns into a sketch.
Basically, you should use the lines to create the shape and sections.
Then, fill the sections with different patterns and ornaments.
If you can’t think of what to draw, draw a line that resembles the profile of a face.
It is actually the most interesting and sophisticated thing to draw.
Then, draw the basic features of that face with loose lines and shapes.
Draw the profile of a face.
Simple draw the outline of a forehead, eye, nice, mouth, and chin.
Fill in the face with basic features if you desire, or use patterns to draw an abstract version of a face.
A face is an example, but you can draw whatever you want.
Use a pen to draw your sketch.
You need a sketch only if you prepare for a large, the wall-size artwork like a mirror.
You need no preparation or sketches if you draw the small or medium size artwork.
Nadia Russ recommends using always a pen to draw in this style so that you can’t erase what you’ve created.
It’s okay if the drawing looks different from what you’ve expected it would be or if you make mistakes.
Use your sense of harmony to fix the composition without eraser.
Do not give up until you feel the drawing is complete.Deciding when the drawing is complete is entirely up to you.
You can stop whenever you can’t think of anything else to add to the drawing.
The best judge here is your sense of harmony.
Creating a NeoPopRealism Egg Draw several patterns.
You can dive into creating the egg if you’d like, but if you are a beginner, it’s okay to start by generating ideas by drawing patterns.
Take out a piece of paper and a pen.
Never use a pencil.
Fill the paper with several separate and unique patterns.
You can use those patterns to fill in your egg when you’re ready.For example, you can draw repeated diamonds, circles, swirls, curvy lines and triangles.
Draw an egg shape on paper.
Once you’ve come up with some patterns, draw the shape of an egg on a piece of paper.
You should only draw the basic outline, and the inside of the “egg” should be empty.
It’s okay if the shape isn’t perfect, but you can redraw it if you aren’t happy with the first shape.
Fill the egg with lines and patterns.
You can put some thought into this if you are a beginner or do it entirely without putting conscious effort into what you’re drawing.
Section your egg off by drawing several lines so that you create “spaces” for your patterns.
Then, fill those spaces with patterns like the ones you practiced.
Don’t stop until the entire egg has been filled—unless you want to leave white space.
Paint your pattern onto a wooden egg.
Your artwork can be finished when you complete the egg on paper, or you can use that egg as a base for a wooden egg.
This isn’t necessary, but it is a way to show off and display what you’ve created.
Take a wooden egg and acrylic paint in the colors of your choice.
Use a thin paintbrush to paint patterns all over the wooden egg.
Wait a few minutes for the paint to dry and then finish by spraying it with a clear varnish.It’s also an option to use transfer paper if you don’t want to start the sketch over completely.
You can also use a marker or pen to draw on the egg if you don’t want to use paint.
